Author has ignored the issues brought up 2 years ago, so I've modified the bad validator from:
5
0
1500 850
3400 1700
800 500
4500 2500
6000 5000

to:
5
0
800 500
1500 850
3400 1700
4500 2500
6000 5000

And now since all tests and validators are pre-sorted by distance, I have mentioned that in the statement, input and constraints.

The indexing of your problem is extremely misleading and  confusing.

You provide the mountains in a list that is unsorted, then ask for the player to give the indices of the mountains that they can see. But instead of indexing based on your list, you actually ask them to index based on the sorted list.
You should just give the mountains as a sorted list so there is no confusion about the indices, or not ask for mountain indices at all and just ask for the mountain distances as a response. To use indices that aren't related to the original list is very confusing.

What's worse is that none of the test cases will actually help a clasher notice this issue if they are giving the indices based on the first list. They will get 100% and only fail on 1 validator "5 other mountains, 3 hidden ".
It's very annoying to get 100% on test cases and then 80% on the actual submission because of hidden  edge cases in validators and misleading statements..

✅ Approved the contribution.

Comment: While still a bit difficult to understand, the statement should be clear enough when one thinks about it a little.
The problem is a simple sort by distance then go over the list, computing the angles to the observers.

Honestly I don't understand.  Are the mountains lined up in a row??   If so, that should be made clear.

If I am in a 3D world anywhere (at any altitude) and there are 4 mountains in various directions, (east, west, south, north, etc), they are all visible to me regardless of their size.  What am I missing?

The idea is good, but the statement is very confusing, so much that I had to look at your answer to understand it.
You should make it clear that 
1) all mountains are aligned together with the observer.
2) If one small mountain is too close to the observer, it will appear very big and hide mountains that are much taller but much farther to the observer.

This should give enough information.

Input section
* Your stub generator and test cases do not match this section - line 1 in the stub generator/test cases is N instead of ALTITUDE, and line 2 is the reverse case.
* Please use "Line 1" instead of "First line" for consistency/clarity.

Constraints section
* I think you mean ≤ instead of < in 2 < N < 10.
* Why not just merge the second and third constraints as 0 < DISTANCE, HEIGHT, ATTITUDE < 10000? 8848 also looks an odd upper bound to me unless the number carries a special meaning.
Thank you for your comment. I have updated the description.
You're right, that wasn't clear enough. I have added some description. Thé mountains are aligned in the same direction. That should answer to your question.

I mean after reading other comments and seeing the examples and guessing, I think I understand. 

But honestly it’s still not clear. You talk about distance can be calculated in 3D but then you’re saying this is just 2D ??

I think you need to make this crystal clear that it is a 2D world that you’re talking about and that the observer is on one end of a 2D mountain range.  I think an image (sketch, drawing) would help a lot.
I have added the 2D-world aspect in the description. I am trying to add a skectch, as you suggested.
